p:
Long‐chain n‐alkanes have been widely used to evaluate the terrestrial influence on the ocean (Eglinton & Eglinton, 2008). In this study, the increasing trend of long‐chain n‐alkanes during 2002–2011 matches the increased rainfall and river discharge after 1997, although there is a small time lag (Figure 3). Meanwhile, rapid increases in brassicasterol and dinosterol after 1997 coincided with increased
TEX
86
H
temperature and long‐chain n‐alkanes in timescale (Figure 4). Liu et al. ( 2016) discovered a significant increase in total organic carbon and nitrogen in sediment cores in the Cygnet Bay after 2000; the C:N ratio and δ 13C indicated the increased organic matter was mainly from marine sources. Furnas and Carpenter ( 2016) found primary production increased ca. twofold in 1990–2013 compared to 1960–1962 in the Kimberley. Thus, there is credible evidence for phytoplankton biomass increase related to climate change in the Kimberley shelf region.
